subject: Introduce test case with class cleanups
commit_message:
Introduce test case with class cleanups

Tempest has a common use case of resources that are setup
at setUpClass time - and thus shared by all tests in the
TestSuite associated to the test class, and which needs to
be cleaned up after all tests in the suite are executed.

We want to implement the resource providers as fixtures,
but we need the ability to schedule a the cleanup of the
fixtures in a safe way, so that it will always happen no
matter what.

This is achieved by implementing a new test base class,
which overrides setUpClass and tearDownClass fixtures,
and implementing an addClassCleanup method.
Any failure during cleanup of the fixtures will be
recorded and raised as MultipleExceptions along with
any failure triggered by class level fixtures.

A new useClassFixture method is exposed as well, which
allows using a fixture from setUpClass in tests.

subject: Introduce resourced test cases
commit_message:
Introduce resourced test cases

Tempest tests use a combination of class and test level fixtures
to setup test resources. Resources defined at class level are
typically re-used by all tests in the test class. Conversely
resources created during test fixtures (or test method) are
destroyed one the test is finished.

Common resources are:
- test credentials and associated networks
- test servers
- ssh validation resources (keypair, security groups, IPs)

The existing codebase grew rather organically, without a
clear direction in terms of resource allocation, so the current
code base contains a combination of different approaches for
managing resources, which are also copy pasted in new Tempest
code and plugins, making the code hard to read, debug and
maintain.

One possible solution is to use testresources, and ditch
class level resources for good. A resource manager object
would become responsible for making sure that resources are
re-used in a similar way as they are today.
The resource managers could then be defined as stable
interfaces in the tempest.lib space, and re-used by plugins.

The current setUpClass performs a number of steps, all of
which would have to be moved somewhere else:
- skip_checks: can be moved as-is in setUp
- setup_credentials: this would become a resource manager
- setup_clients: aliasing of clients is a bit confusing as
  it is today, since clients are aliased and re-aliased.
  This can be done in setUp initially, and it would have
  to be solved eventually
- resource_setup: this would be managed by resource mgrs

The main reason why this was not done yet, is that it is
likely to create a lot of churn in the codebase, for an
unclear benefit. The current code base already provides
a mechanism to allocate resources by setting class
attributes, but that mechanism has turned out to be
hard to debug, and testresources would not provide a
huge benefit in that direction either.

The main advantage would probably be ditching class level
resources, which create a confusing subunit stream with
skips and errors happening at class level, and also
create inconsistent and sub-optimaal resource usage in
tests, which in a f ew cases lead to race conditions and
issues in the gate.

With this commit I start a PoC on this to get a more
concrete idea of how this would look like and get people
opinion on it, before we decide to continue or stop this
direction for good.

The alternative approach would be to create class level
fixtures, which would provide a common way to handle class
level resources. Class level fixture would also go into
tempest.lib as a stable interface, see:
I5d4f0477893432a84ba98d8a596a6d6d0fc9a7a0

Partially-implements: bp tempest-stable-fixtures

subject: Increase tcp_retries2 value
commit_message:
Increase tcp_retries2 value

Current value of 5 results in socket operation timeout after ~12.9
seconds. This is a bit too low, e.g. we've seen RabbitMQ network
splits in production.

This 12.9s amount is equal as 0.2*(2^1+2^2+..2^5), where 0.2 is a
retry timeout (RTO) that is calculated by kernel on a per-socket
basis. But in fast local networks it usually almost equal to minimum
values of 0.2s hardcoded in linux kernel (and BTW, RFC says that
minimum value should be 1s).

On the other hand, comment in netconfig.pp says that our target
timeout is ~54 seconds. And changing tcp_retries2 to 7 is consistent
with that comment - tests an live env show that resulting timeout is
~52.2s

Change-Id: Ib52f40ef1017a9da5a29cd62fb744a4597860763

subject: libvirt: Remove redundant bdm serial mangling and saving during swap_volume
commit_message:
libvirt: Remove redundant bdm serial mangling and saving during swap_volume

During an initial swap_volume call the serial of the original volume was
previously stashed in the connection_info of the new volume by the
compute layer. This was used by I19d5182d11 to allow the virt driver to
lookup and update the existing BDM with the new volume's connection_info
after it had been used by connect_volume.

Future calls to swap_volume in the compute layer would not
update the serial found in the old volume connection_info. This would
result in an invalid serial being copied into the new volume
connection_info and used to preform a lookup of a BDM that didn't exist.

To correct this we now explicitly set the serial of the new volume to
that of the new volume id. While the correct serial id should already be
present in the connection_info provided by most backend Cinder volume
drivers the act of updating this dict is required by our own functional
tests to invoke a failure case :

https://git.io/vDmRE

The serial is updated once more to match the volume id returned
by os-migrate-volume-completion prior to the BDM being updated in the
compute layer.

The BDM lookup and save from the virt layer is also removed as the
compute layer retains a reference to new_cinfo and will update the BDM
with this, including any modifications, at the end of swap_volume.

Finally, the associated Tempest admin test is also extended by the
following change to now attempt a second volume swap to verify these
changes :

I2a2c80a164b9f75d0e7e0503a24194bedfc0e66b

Conflicts:
        nova/compute/manager.py

NOTE(lyarwood): Simple conflict caused by I90d4ffcb adding an error
notification for swap_volume.

Closes-bug: #1661016

subject: WIP: Make it easier to avoid live-migration timeouts
commit_message:
WIP: Make it easier to avoid live-migration timeouts

If you are having live-migrations timeout, and you want to avoid that
happening, the key configuration options to consider now are:

* live_migration_downtime
* live_migration_completion_timeout

Where live_migration_downtime tunes how much guest downtime you are
willing to tolerate during the live-migration and
live_migration_completion_timeout defines how long you are willing to
wait for a 1GB ram (with no storage to move) to have a small enough
amount of memory to copy that it can happen in under
live_migration_downtime seconds.

After this change, by default, we spend half of the completion_timeout
time ramping up to the max downtime defined in live_migration_downtime.
This means we try and avoid guest downtime, but take a little longer.

If you want to avoid this ramp up, and start with
live_migration_downtime as the max downtime straight away, then set
live_migration_time_to_max_downtime = 0

You can use live_migration_time_to_max_downtime to decide how fast or
slow to ramp up the max guest downtime, but usually you should be able
to get what you want without having to consider that configuration
setting.

live_migration_time_to_max_downtime is replacing
live_migration_downtime_steps and live_migration_downtime_delay.
The single configuration more closely matches how deployers should be
thinking about this problem.

too, have the resulting files put into the resultdir supplied by the
user.

easier to understand.

subject: Decrement quota usage when deleting an instance in cell0
commit_message:
Decrement quota usage when deleting an instance in cell0

When we fail to schedule an instance, e.g. there are no hosts
available, conductor creates the instance in the cell0 database
and deletes the build request. At this point quota usage
has been incremented in the main 'nova' database.

When the instance is deleted, the build request is already gone
so _delete_while_booting returns False and we lookup the instance
in cell0 and delete it from there, but that flow wasn't decrementing
quota usage like _delete_while_booting was.

This change adds the same quota usage decrement handling that
_delete_while_booting performs.

NOTE(mriedem): This change also pulls in some things from
I7de87dce216835729283bca69f0eff59a679b624 which is not being
backported to Ocata since in Pike it solves a slightly different
part of this quota usage issue. In Pike the cell mapping db_connection
is actually stored on the context object when we get the instance
from nova.compute.api.API.get(). So the fix in Pike is slightly
different from Ocata. However, what we need to pull from that Pike
change is:

1. We need to target the cell that the instance lives in to get the
   flavor information when creating the quota reservation.

2. We need to change the functional regression test to assert that
   the bug is fixed.

The code and tests are adjusted to be a sort of mix between both
changes in Pike without requiring a full backport of the 2nd
part of the fix in Pike.

Change-Id: I4cb0169ce0de537804ab9129bc671d75ce5f7953
Partial-Bug: #1670627
(cherry picked from commit 018068c4caac324643c7c6a4360fad855dd096eb)

Decrease overall run time when identity auth is set to v3.

This patch avoids executing time.sleep(1) in rbac_utils, when
Keystone v3 auth is enabled, which greatly reduces run time
(approximately by 5 min or more). Thus, this patch also changes
post_test_hook to forcibly set Keystone v3 auth in the tempest
gates, so that tests run much faster.

Currently time.sleep(1) is used to avoid rounding issues with the
"created_at" field when creating a token. This field drops the
milliseconds from the time field. Attempting to use a token before
the time in the "created_at" field results in an error, meaning that
it is necessary to do time.sleep(1). However, with Keystone v3 this
is not the case, so this time.sleep(1) can be avoided with v3, resulting

commit_message:
Switch ns-metadata-proxy to haproxy

Due to the high memory footprint of current Python ns-metadata-proxy,
it has to be replaced with a lighter process to avoid OOM conditions in
large environments.

This patch spawns haproxy through a process monitor using a pidfile.
This allows tracking the process and respawn it if necessary as it was
done before. Also, it implements an upgrade path which consists of
detecting any running Python instance of ns-metadata-proxy and
replacing them by haproxy. Therefore, upgrades will take place by
simply restarting neutron-l3-agent and neutron-dhcp-agent.

According to /proc/<pid>/smaps, memory footprint goes down from ~50MB
to ~1.5MB.

Also, haproxy is added to bindep in order to ensure that it's installed.

subject: Hack to add noauth support
commit_message:
Hack to add noauth support

Cinder client doesn't support noauth authentication and I believe that
adding it properly will require considerable changes, including some
refactoring.

This patch doesn't try to provide a nice solution, but instead a hack
that allows us to play with it until we get it all sorted out.

It should be compatible with current calls, and for it to work it
requires 3 things:

- Setting noauth: --os-auth-system=noauth
                  or OS_AUTH_SYSTEM=noauth
- User-id: --os-user-id=uuid_or_name
            or OS_USER_ID=uuid_or_name
- URL: --os-cinder-url=http://127.0.0.1:8776 or
  OS_CINDER_URL=http://127.0.0.1:8776

The project id sent to Cinder will be the same as the user id, like
Cinder does if it only receives one of them in the header, unless it is
provided with:

- Project-id: --os-project-id=uuid_or_name
              or OS_PROJECT_ID=uuid_or_name

subject: Fix support for cinder ceph rbd on Ocata
commit_message:
Fix support for cinder ceph rbd on Ocata

As of Ocata, the ceph key used to access a specific Cinder
Ceph backend must match the name of the key used by cinder,
with an appropriate secret configured for libvirt use with
the cephx key used by the cinder-ceph charm.

Add support for the new ceph-access relation to allow
nova-compute units to communicate with multiple ceph
backends using different cephx keys and user names.

The lead cinder-ceph unit will generate a UUID for use in
the cinder configuration file, and for use by the remote
nova-compute units when configuring libvirt secrets,
ensuring that both ends of the integration match up.

The side effect of this change is that nova-compute will
have a key for use with its own ephemeral backend ceph
access, and a key for each cinder ceph backend configured
in the deployment.

Closes-Bug: 1671422
